content.description: Very thin tip liebacking and face climbing up the right facing corner.
content.protection: Top rope from 2 bolt anchor. No known leads.
content.location:
The right side of the ledge system that

The Man Who Fell to Earth

starts on. Just left of the start of

Caliente

.

content.description: The left arching thin crack.  Sustained and difficult to protect crack climbing.
content.location:
Across the notch from the top of the

(f) Limp Dick

Pinnacle.

climbs.name: The Source
climbs.fa: Ivan Couch and Mike Dent, Early 70's

content.description:
Suicides finest route.

NOT.

Think of all the worst words used to describe a route.  Chimney, flared, loose, dirty, often wet, mossy, funky, somewhat difficult to protect.  Put them all in one sentence.  Congratulations!  You just described The Source!

So named because the FA party felt that the route was "the source of all evil".  Never a line on this one for some reason.

This route is on superb rock with great climbing, and has a tricky crux. The headwall of the route is unusually steep rock for Suicide.

Pitch 1: Climb one of, Paisano Chimney, Clockwork Orange, or Euphoria.

Pitch 2: Follow the bolts directly across from the ledge. Slightly runout slab climbing leads to a small sloping ledge at the base of the right side of the Caliente inclusion.  Steeper edging brings one to the crux at the top of the inclusion.  From there, continue on easier climbing to the top.
content.protection: 9 bolts, plus gear for whatever first pitch is climbed. Cams up to 2" or 3" for the summit belay (or, there is now a 2 bolt belay in the vicinity as well.)
content.location:
Right of

Caliente

. Start at base of Paisano Chimney.

climbs.name: Runout in Reverse
climbs.fa: Troy Mayr and Charles Cole, July 1987

content.description: This short face route has some fun moves.  To get to the start of the climb, scramble up and left along the base of the Sunshine Face, past Paisano Chimney.  A short rappel leads back to the base.
content.protection: Bolts (5/16") plus a few small wired nuts and RP's

climbs.name: Paisano Chimney
climbs.fa: Pat Callis and Larry Harrell, May, 1968

content.description: To get to this climb, scramble up and left along the base of the Sunshine Face.  The route follows a deep, narrow chimney up to the base of Paisano Pinnacle.  A crux overhang (fairly nice) leads to a tight, unpleasant 20 foot long squeeze chimney.  At the top of the climb, walk and chimney behind Paisano Pinnacle to the broad Paisano Ledge.  From there, you can downclimb Bye Gully or do a route (e.g. Continuation) to the top of the rock.

climbs.name: The Man Who Fell to Earth

content.description: Follow discontinuous thin cracks (10d) onto the face above (11a).  Kind of strange climbing that proves to be quite entertaining, with a little bit of run-out climbing.  A high quality route on good rock.
content.protection: Bolts, thin gear, cams to 1.5".  Maybe something around 2" for the belay.
content.location:
Scramble up to the top of the ledges left of the start of

Caliente

(just right of

B.C.'s Ouch Chimney

).

climbs.name: Hit It, Ethel
climbs.fa: Tom Gilje, Terry Ayers, and Mike Lechlinski, 1991

content.description: Desperate moves over the roof lead to unprotected face climbing above (5.9).  Arranging protection can include double ropes, using one rope to "lasso" the obvious knob.  Hard moves in a great position.
content.location: Start from the ledge underneath the ouside face of Paisano Pinnacle.

content.description: From the 2 bolt anchor below Chisholm Trail go left up a 3rd/4th class gully passing The Source and eventually reaching a pine tree.  Immediately after the tree turn 90 degrees right and climb up a 5.6 hand to finger crack to the top of the cliff.  Not nearly as bad as the name suggests.  The final crack is quite fun.
content.location: Start is the same as for Chisholm Trail although technically the 5.5ish approach to Chisholm trail just right of Runout in Reverse may be considered part of this route.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Follow the large obvious flake system up to the base of the pinnacle.

Pitch 2: Turn the overhang on bolts and a move of aid, then continue up the face on 5.9 climbing. Outrageous location on the face of the pinnacle.
content.location:
Start just right of

Paisano Chimney

. Follows a flake and then the ouside face of Paisano Pinnacle.

climbs.name: Domestic Friction
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller, Jim Robertson and Mike Brewer, August 1999  FL: Chris Miller & Cheryl Basye, July 2000

content.description:
Well-protected and interesting face/friction moves with the crux just past the 3rd bolt.

Erroneously called "Miller Time" in the current guidebook.
content.location:
Just left of

Runout in Reverse

.

climbs.name: Clockwork Orange
climbs.fa: Kelly Vaught, Bob Gaines, Frank Brentwood, 1998

content.description: Follow a crack up to three bolts on the arete of the orange block.
content.location:
Start at the base of

Paisano Chimney

.

climbs.name: Chisholm Trail
climbs.fa: Fred Zeil, Eric Erickson, and Tim Powell, 1977

content.description: A right facing flare that presents challenging thin crack and face moves.  Face climb into the start of the flare (10a), then follow the crack (11b/c) to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection:
Several thin up to 2"

2 FP, 1 bolt
content.location:
Located between The Source and

B.C.'s Ouch Chimney

. Approach past the base of Caliente.

content.description:
Superb climbing on great rock.

Pitch 1: Scramble up easy 5th class climbing and belay on a ledge at a 2 bolt anchor (40' left of

Paisano Chimney

). A short crack leads to 5.10c face climbing that takes you to the black inclusion. A series of reaches presents the crux of the pitch on the inclusion. Above the crux, runout 5.10d climbing takes one into a left leaning arch that contains a 2 bolt ring equipped belay.

Pitch 2: 5.10c climbing follows the arch to it's end, then up the easy face. A variation can also be done to the second pitch: from the belay step down a few moves, then pull over the arch and climb just above the lip of the arch (10d), tending left.

It is also possible to do this as a one pitch route, but rope drag factors in.

climbs.name: B.C.'s Ouch Chimney
climbs.fa: Ivan Couch, Mike Cohen, and Bob Kamps

content.description: Despite the name, you won't be doing much chimneying on this climb.  It goes up a wide, very shallow slot on good rock, giving a full pitch of sustained and varied climbing.  This route is in the sun all day.  Getting up to the base of the climb requires a few 5.5 moves that many people do unroped.
content.protection: standard rack with a good selection of wired nuts
